title: Environmental Inequity & Injustice
text:
What is Environmental Inequity/Injustice?

Marginalized groups within our population systematically experience higher levels of environmental risk, and enjoy worse/limited access to quality nature and the environment than their counterparts.

experienced along lines of race and class through settler-colonialist violence, anti-Black racism, classism, etc.
access to a healthy environment is a human right









not a new phenomenon, but a relatively new framework, within the last 60-70 years but really in the 90s
there are many ways that environmental injustice can manifest, including health outcomes related to toxic and polluted environments, worse access to the benefits of green spaces, gentrification, etc
environmental injustice in Canada is experienced along lines of race and class
this is due to our society’s foundation in colonization, anti-Black racism, and classism
recently, Canada legislated that access to a healthy environment is a human right, that all Canadians should have access to
this follows the UN stating the same, and many other countries making similar legislation
examples?

title: Environmental Inequity & Injustice
text:
What is Environmental Inequity/Injustice?




 





“… without a doubt, racism influences the likelihood of exposure to environmental and health risks and the accessibility to health care.
Racism provides whites of all class levels with an “edge” in gaining access to a healthy physical environment.” - Robert D. Bullard, 1993






 







Nova Scotia’s Toxic Sites








Robert Bullard is considered one of the main forces behind the contemporary environmental justice framework. He has written papers, books, news articles, etc on the topic. One of the most integral works has this quote
an example that gained attention in Canada after Ingrid Wallace’s book Something in the Water (later turned into a movie directed by Elliott Page), is the environmental injustice faced by Black and Indigenous communities in Nova Scotia
we see on this graph that almost every single Black and Indigenous community in Nova Scotia is within range of a toxic industry site - leading to critical health outcomes in dozens of communities
read the book! Watch the movie! Has anyone heard of it?

title: Environmental Inequity & Injustice
text:
Origins of Environmental Justice






Memphis Garbage Strike







Formation of NECAG







environmental justice movement really starts with the presence of adverse health outcomes from pollution

e.g., cancer in Halifax
e.g., air pollution in LA (Bullard)

has expanded to include other aspects of health and wellbeing

tree canopy
access to green space

The Memphis garbage strike of 1968 is considered one of the first movements in the environmental justice movement, where Black sanitation workers went on strike to protest the environmental conditions of their labour (was MLK Jr’s last event before his assassination)
A decade later in 1979, we see the formation of the Northeast Community Action Group in Houston, formed by Black homeowners protesting the development of a landfill 1500 ft from a public school in their neighbourhood. It was the first lawsuit that charged environmental discrimination in the US.

title: Environmental Inequity & Injustice
text:
Politics of Citation




 





Citation in academia can be an act of resistance, an act of aspiration
The ideas and theories of environmental justice, racism, inequity, reparations are rooted in a history created by Black women, Indigenous women, marginalized groups and people that will never be cited








my ideas and learning on these topics has been informed by reading and listening to people in other fields and non-academics alike. People like bell hooks, Mariame Kaba, Angela Davis, Leanne Simpson, Eve Tuck, Sara Ahmed, Haunani-Kay Trask, and many many others that I know (or don’t know) have formed the world and perspective in which I operate

title: Environmental Inequity & Injustice
text:
Environmental Justice Framework

Incorporates principle right of all people to be protected from environmental degradation
Adopts a public health model of prevention
Shifts burden of proof to actors who do harm and/or do not protect marginalized groups
Uses impact instead of intent to infer discrimination
Uses targeted actions and resources

Bullard, 2008

The environmental justice framework that we know today, developed by Robert Bullard, operates on 5 main principles. 1. Now, as we mentioned, the right of all people to be protected from environmental degradation has become somewhat mainstream with the UN declaring a human right to a healthy environment 2. The public health model of prevention instead of reaction is really key here, and something that goes overlooked or ignored many times. In Canada, we see this with mining companies a lot. Due to the Canadian government’s lax regulations, mining companies break rules, degrade the environment and pollute Indigenous lands, declare bankruptcy and move on leaving legacies of injustice in Indigenous communities and are nowhere to clean up the mess, let alone prevent it 3. Shifts burden of proof to actors who do harm. We saw the NECAG law case, where they lost because they had the burden of proof upon them to prove that this was going to harm their children, their seniors, themselves. It is critical that the burden of proof is not on marginalized communities, that those in development of any kind must themselves prove that it is not harmful, unjust, inequitable. 4. This again, has become more mainstream since 2008. It does not matter if your intent was not to enact environmental injustice, if the impact is that it did – that is the problem. 5. Target resources where people need them the most, and moving away from objective science to include human values and priorities.

title: Environmental Inequity & Injustice
text:
“Canada’s” Environment







Parks Canada







Mining Resistance




Figure 1: Canada’s environment was taken from Indigenous peoples who managed the land since time immemorial.



Environmental inequity and racism has existed in Canada for as long as settler colonialism has. - We can (and should) think of the colonization of Canada as the first act of environmental racism (among many other things).
We see environmental injustice in Canada through countless historical and contemporary examples. The creation of National Parks was done to remove Indigenous People’s from the land in the name of “conservation”. Today, we see government and toxic industries taking and destroying Indigenous lands without permission, such as the Ring of Fire in Ontario.

title: Environmental Inequity & Injustice
text:
Injustice by Design


Urban planning is defined as a social endeavor that has a distinct set of goals designed to reach an “optimal strategy” determined by those in power (Alexander, 1992)



In our society, the inequity and injustice we face is by design, it is intentional. That does not mean, that individual actors are responsible for the existence of racism, but it does mean that this is not a natural phenomenon. For example, whiteness is a construct that was invented for a specific purpose, the subjugation of non-white people. And of course, even though it is made up it is also very real.
We also know that our design reflects our society. So when we build cities, highly designed and managed cities, they reflect the injustices of our society back onto us if we do not actively work to disrupt that. Again, these are systems and so they will run without our input. We need to make active effort if we want them to do anything else.
Because urban planning is done by those in power, and the goals of urban planning are most often determined by those in power, it reflects the injustice of our society.
We see this in so many ways in cities, one of those ways is tree canopy cover and urban heat. We see this here in Montreal, in so many neighbourhoods but this example is extremely stark.

title: Environmental Inequity & Injustice
text:
Ecology’s Role




A “traditional” approach to ecology results:

Environmental inequity
Misunderstanding of urban ecological systems









Radio-Canada Article










A traditional approach to ecology results in gentrification, prioritization of certain populations, legacy effects
When we focus only on the capacity for a system to produce ecological benefits, we are ignoring the social and management side of the system, and who those benefits are supposed to be for
It results in environmental inequity , but it also results in a misunderstanding of the system
If we only focused on the fact that areas with less vegetation are hotter, we would miss fundamental aspects of the trend, such as the fact that those are the neighbourhoods with less immigrants

Maintaining and providing ecosystem services

the eurocentric worldview of nature as separate from people has driven conservation in the western world for a long time
we must be careful and intentional when doing conservation

title: Environmental Inequity & Injustice
text:
Medellín’s Greenbelt




 







Empresa de Desarrollo Urbano (EDU), Municipio de Medellín







 





Medellín, like other cities, wants to improve resiliency, decrease heat islands, reduce flooding
People living in high-risk climate zones are poor, marginalized communities
Greenbelt was proposed to address sprawl, ecological, and social issues
Estimated to affect 230,000 residents







Greenbelt aims to protect areas surrounding Medellín and protect sprawl, increase climate resilience, and have many other important ecological benefits
Residents do not want to be evicted for many reasons including concern over where they will be moved to, that they will receive insufficient funding, that they will lose their social networks and ability to work, etc.
Residents think the government is over estimating risk to remove them
Design is not congruent with how residents view nature - built up “techy” version of nature that doesn’t feel natural to residents
Creating private land where residents used to live
Exclusion of community voices, superimposing the “city’s” vision

1. Take out a sheet of paper (I have some if you don’t)
2. Write a response to any of these discussion points:

What is an idea you have for improving environmental equity in Montréal? Why do you think it would work?

Do you have examples of science that you think should have considered environmental justice and didn’t? Why should they? Why didn’t they?
